docs.lead_paragraph: Easy access to a morning-after pill for contraception does not influence the degree to which women have unprotected sex, a new study has found. The study, published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association, covered 2,117 women ages 15 to 24 in the San Francisco area who said they wanted to avoid pregnancy. Some were told to obtain emergency contraception from pharmacists without a prescription, others were given pills and others were told to get pills from a clinic as needed. At the end of the study, about 4 in 10 women in each group reported having unprotected sex and 8 percent in all three groups had become pregnant.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: No Link Found For Pill And Sexual Behavior

docs.abstract: Study finds that easy access to morning-after pill for contraception does not influence degree to which women have unprotected sex (S)
docs.snippet: Easy access to a morning-after pill for contraception does not influence the degree to which women have unprotected sex, a new study has found. The study, published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association, covered 2,117 women ages...

docs.lead_paragraph: It does not look like anyone's mother, and the baby it delivers has none of the emotional appeal of a newborn. But a lifelike birth simulator developed at Johns Hopkins University may provide some important new information about problem deliveries in real mothers and infants. The birth simulator, which started out as a research project in engineering, has now been used to determine the best way to deliver a baby whose shoulders become stuck in the birth canal, a condition called shoulder dystocia.

headline.main: Device Allows Doctors To Practice Deliveries

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Allen, Johns Hopkins University biomedical engineering professor, heads project that developed lifelike birth simulator for training and research; Dr Edith Gurewitsch, obstetrics and gynecology assistant professor, is working with team to test machine in difficult births involving shoulder dystocia; early findings, published in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, suggest that Rubin's maneuver, which rotates baby's trunk, uses half force of most commonly used delivery technique to deliver baby with shoulders stuck in birth canal; benefits of simulator discussed (M)
docs.snippet: The birth simulator has now been used to determine the best way to deliver a baby whose shoulders become stuck in the birth canal.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN JOURNAL OF OBSTETRICS AND GYNECOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. William A. Silverman, a physician whose studies of newborns at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center helped alter the treatment of premature infants and gave many parents greater say in their babies' fates, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 87. The cause was renal failure, said his daughter, Jen Silverman.

headline.main: William A. Silverman, 87, Dies; Leading Neonatologist of 1950's

docs.abstract: Dr William A Silverman, leading neonatologist, dies at age 87; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. William A. Silverman was a physician whose studies of newborns at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center helped alter the treatment of premature infants.
